The XRF technique was also used to examine David, Michelangelo's masterpiece. By analysing the dust and dirt on David’s nose, experts confirmed the statue could be safely restored. https://t.co/8HUltmYA2Q

How does X-ray fluorescence spectrometry work? The beam is focused by an X-ray lens at a selected spot on the sample. The analysis takes a few minutes and does not harm the piece of art. Data from the analysis then reveals the sample's composition, confirming its authenticity. https://t.co/N0neQ5BkfC
With the help of equipment from the IAEA, experts discovered that the piece was in good condition and was in fact made of 90% pure gold. https://t.co/8qD59Nsr6u

After a three-year 🌍 search, #OnThisDay in 2006, police recovered the art piece from a forest outside #Vienna. Police and conservators turned to X-ray fluorescence spectrometry (XRF) to uncover clues about its condition and investigate how to best protect it further. https://t.co/EucnYK1IO0

After graduating as a doctor from the @EdinburghUni, Prout ran a medical practice while researching the chemistry of the human body in order to understand its functions and diseases.
While this turned out to not be entirely true, this early endeavor led to a better understanding of the existence of various chemical elements and atomic structures.
Born #onthisday in 1785, Prout is most well-known for ‘Prout’s Hypothesis’, which stated that the atomic weights of elements are multiples of the atomic weight of #hydrogen.

When uranium is taken from the earth, the ore or rock typically contains only about 0.1% uranium. After extracting it and making it into a ‘yellowcake’, the uranium concentration in it has been raised to more than 75%!

500x more abundant than gold & as common as tin, uranium is a slightly radioactive metal that occurs throughout earth's crust. Most rocks & soils, and many rivers & seawater, contain uranium. Uranium-based fuel is expected to remain a basic, reliable source for low-carbon power.
#Uranium, the fuel that enables nuclear power plants to generate electricity, is a heavy, dense and radioactive metal. This makes it a potent source of concentrated energy.
What you see in this picture is “yellowcake” coming off a conveyor line. And what’s the main ingredient of yellowcake? That’s right: uranium! #TIL https://t.co/GFt56MRht0

Today, the periodic table of elements still reflects Moseley’s findings, and atomic batteries are now used in places where long battery life is crucial, like spacecraft for example. https://t.co/uMk3dK8Mps
By doing so, Moseley discovered a mathematical relationship between X-ray wavelengths and the atomic numbers of metals. This became known as Moseley’s law.
A year later, Moseley was able to determine X-ray wavelengths by observing and measuring the X-ray ranges of metals, thus pioneering the use of the X-ray Spectroscopy method.
In 1912, Moseley developed the first atomic battery, or beta cell, when he insulated beta particles emitted from radium to generate 150,000 volts of long-lasting energy.

Today is Henry Moseley’s birthday! 👏⚛

He was the inventor of the first atomic battery and the first scientist to give physical meaning to the atomic weights of the periodic table of elements. 

#TIL #Thread https://t.co/DHAnjIT3Gd

Today several countries have networks of atomic clocks that are kept synchronized to maintain a stable time scale.
In the case of a beam of caesium atoms like the one used in the original clock, the clock can calculate the exact number of radiation cycles of a caesium atom per second: 9,192,631,770!
An atomic clock tracks an electrical oscillator regulated by the natural vibration frequencies of an atomic system.

Ten years later Louis Essen and Jack Parry designed and built the world's first caesium atomic clock at the National Physical Laboratory in England. This transformed the way we measure and use time: the clock only loses around one second over the course of 300 years.

Did you know clocks lose time over the years? To get more precise, in 1945, Isidor Rabi, a physics professor at Columbia University, proposed the construction of the first atomic clock. ⚛️ #TIL #Thread https://t.co/JqUOhsISNH

For his contribution to the development of the CAT scanning technique, Cormack, together with Hounsfield, was awarded the @NobelPrize in Physiology or Medicine in 1979.
With the theoretical possibility of such a technique established by Cormack, the electrical engineer Godfrey Newbold Hounsfield and his colleagues constructed the first CAT scanner in 1971.

Cormack developed the mathematical formulas necessary to develop this technique, which involves using X-ray images taken from multiple angles in order to create a detailed cross-sectional image of the body.

#OnThisDay in 1924, physicist Allan McLeod Cormack was born! Cormack was instrumental in the development of the diagnostic technique known as computerized axial tomography (CAT) scanning. #TIL #OTD #Thread https://t.co/4Dwu6INDFC

This experiment helped disprove the theory of physicist J.J. Thomson, who believed that atoms were spheres with electrons distributed evenly throughout.

The experiments involved directing a beam of alpha particles at gold foil. Through their observation that most of the alpha particles passed through the foil, w/ some bouncing back, they concluded atoms mostly consist of empty space, w/ an electron cloud surrounding the nucleus.

This series of experiments, conducted together with Hans Geiger under the supervision of Ernest Rutherford, led to the discovery that all atoms have most of their mass concentrated in their nuclei, which always have a positive charge.

Happy birthday, Ernest Marsden! His research has helped scientists understand the composition of #atoms. 

Born #OnThisDay in 1889, Marsden is widely recognized for the Geiger-Marsden experiments, also known as the "Rutherford gold foil experiment". #TIL #OTD https://t.co/SS6dksECM7

The periodic table of elements has grown over time, but Mendeleev’s periodic law has held true. https://t.co/PbDVHhQZEw

Although not immediately accepted, his work gained international attention when elements he predicted were discovered. His diagram, known as the periodic table of elements, is widely used today and is a cornerstone of modern chemistry. https://t.co/Kj1q4icI5i

Determined to find a better way to classify elements, he formulated the periodic law, which states that many properties of elements tend to recur in a systematic manner with increasing #atomic number.

In 1860, he was invited to Karlsruhe, #Germany for the first-ever international #chemistry conference, which highlighted the need to standardize chemistry and had a great influence on Mendeleev’s work.

Born in 1834 in #Siberia, #Russia 🇷🇺, Dmitri Mendeleev overcame a challenging childhood to become both a teacher and an academic chemist in St. Petersburg, publishing 400 books and articles throughout his life.
🧵 Today is Dmitri #Mendeleev’s birthday! He is best known for creating one of the most iconic emblems in all of modern science: the periodic table of the elements. #TIL https://t.co/0SHDXuGkKM

Hofstadter created a thallium-activated sodium iodide gamma-ray detector, for which he filed a patent in 1948. This type of detector remains a popular tool for gamma-ray spectroscopy to this day.

Hofstadter contributed to the development of nuclear medicine, specifically the use of gamma-ray spectroscopy techniques such as positron emission tomography. These medical imaging techniques are used for the diagnosis and monitoring of cancer as well as neurological conditions.
He is also known for his accurate prediction of two types of meson, which are subatomic particles consisting of one quark and one antiquark: the omega-meson and the rho-meson.

Scientists are also looking at how they can use X-rays to further studies on nuclear fusion.
Today we can thank Röntgen and the scientists who built on his discovery for the many innovative ways we now use X-rays to improve lives and help people around the world.

They are also used to check the quality of everyday items like car tires, cables and wires, and even airplanes through a method called non-destructive testing (NDT), which draws on a combination of X-rays and gamma rays.
When used in art and cultural artefact restoration, restorers can assess damage and uncover details hidden in artefacts, unlocking a wealth of information about the past.

While many of us are probably most familiar with Röntgen’s X-rays when seeing doctors treat broken bones, and in some languages, X-rays are even called röntgen, but X-rays actually have a wide variety of uses.

Wilhelm Röntgen coined the name X-ray when he used these rays to create an image of his wife’s hand on a photographic plate revealing her bones.
In 1901, this achievement made him the first person to ever win the @NobelPrize in #Physics.

Happy Birthday, Wilhelm Röntgen! The father of X-Rays and diagnostic radiology was born exactly 176 years ago #OnThisDay.

These californium-emitted neutrons are also an effective tool in healthcare. They can be used to treat certain types of cervical and brain cancers, particularly when other radiation therapies are ineffective.

Each microgram of fresh #californium produces 139 million neutrons per minute, which makes it a strong neutron emitter. This makes californium useful for some nuclear reactors that rely on neutrons as a start-up source for chain reactions.

The discovery of #californium was announced 71 years ago #onthisday, after it was synthesized by a team of physicists at the @UCBerkeley Radiation Laboratory.

"IAEA has important roles to play in technology innovation: as an advisor on technology and at the same time as provider of safety standards and security guidance." - IAEA Director General @rafaelmgrossi
"To reach #NetZero, we need a decade of supercharged innovation across of low-carbon technologies and we need to start now," says @NTI_WMD @ErnestMoniz
"Decarbonizing industry is very important and on remote locations, such as mines, #microreactors can play an important part," says @NTI_WMD @ErnestMoniz

"Microreactors provide a focused and effective response to a niche demand in a climate-efficient way. We need to find answers to some technical and regulatory issues – and we are working on that," says IAEA Chief @rafaelmgrossi

"A major benefit is very long life of the reactor without need for refueling. There are issues that remain to be worked out: non-proliferation and security related to manufacturing and transport. It is the role of the IAEA to lead in this," says @NTI_WMD @ErnestMoniz

"Early deployment in North America will likely happen through public-private partnerships. Reactors will be produced in factories and shipped to locations of use. This can lead to a major cost reduction and increased economic competitiveness," says @NTI_WMD @ErnestMoniz

"Microreactors must be part of the equation towards #NetZero. They operate autonomously and can be used by countries that do not yet have the technology to build and operate larger nuclear power plants." - IAEA Chief @rafaelmgrossi

"The IAEA provides a platform for countries introducing new technologies like #microreactors. We can support business models to be compatible with safeguards considerations and safety standards. This is our role," says IAEA Chief @rafaelmgrossi
"The IAEA can provide vision and assistance to all the member countries of the Agency. I look forward to the promulgation of this technology in a safe and secure way," @NTI_WMD @ErnestMoniz
"Microgrids are needed to provide resilience to smart grids of the future. #Microreactors will be key for remote communities or industrial operations, replacing diesel," @NTI_WMD @ErnestMoniz
"The attention on the need for carbon free power is being elevated around the world, so a discussion on #microreactors is very timely," says @NTI_WMD @ErnestMoniz

Happening now: IAEA Chief @RafaelmGrossi and @NTI_WMD @ErnestMoniz discuss current status and what the future holds to #microreactors. Watch live https://t.co/RRsZjylq08 or follow live tweeting here ↓ https://t.co/bKTCCtv83a

Today, it is a useful tool for treating certain types of bone #cancer and is also a source of radiation sometimes used for industrial radiography, which is a technique used to test the quality of products and production processes in industry.
Radium was once thought to have curative properties and was used as an additive in everyday products, but it was soon found to be too radioactive for daily use.

To find out what it was, Marie Curie dissolved, filtered & repeatedly crystallized several tonnes of pitchblende from 1899 to 1902. This process left behind around 1mg of what turned out to be radium. In 1911 the Curies shared @NobelPrize in Chemistry for the discovery of radium.

The Curies were experimenting with pitchblende, a common uranium-rich mineral ore. After extracting refined #uranium from the mineral, they found that the remaining materials were still #radioactive ☢️.

119 years ago #OnThisDay Pierre and Marie Curie announced they had isolated one gram of #radium — the first ever sample of this radioactive element naturally found in uranium and in thorium.

It was the 1st time one element had been changed to another under full human control. This discovery has helped scientists understand how they can manipulate particles on a subatomic level in an effort to better understand the structure and function of matter.

This achievement earned them the @NobelPrize in #Physics in 1951.
Cockcroft and Walton developed an accelerator that generates extremely penetrating radiation. They then used this accelerator to bombard lithium with protons and effectively split its nucleus into two helium atoms.

89 years ago #onthisday, the course of nuclear physics took a new turn when John Cockcroft and Ernest Walton split the atom⚛️ using a particle accelerator for the first time. #Thread #TIL https://t.co/gqaJzC5xkk

Studies of this transformation process earned Curie and his colleagues the @NobelPrize in Physics in 1903. Their work helped to lay the foundation for nuclear #physics and #chemistry, marking a critical step toward the many peaceful uses of nuclear science and technology.

While investigating the properties of #radium, an unknown element at the time, Pierre and his collaborators found that a speck of radium was constantly emitting heat. This heat turned out to be the first discovery of #radiation.
Born #onthisday in 1859, Pierre, working with Marie Curie and Henri Becquerel, was a pioneer in the field of #nuclear science and radioactivity.

Today we celebrate the birthday of Pierre Curie, a Nobel Laureate known for his work on #radioactivity.

Correction: Maria Goeppert Mayer was the second woman to win a @NobelPrize in Physics.
Although her nuclear shell model has since evolved, it laid an important foundation for our current understanding of the atomic nucleus structure and how it behaves.

In the late 1940s, Goeppert Mayer developed a mathematical model for the structure of #nuclear shells. This model helped explain the configurations for atomic nuclei, and it earned her a share of the 1963 @NobelPrize in Physics.

Thirty years later, after the development of lasers, scientists were finally able to prove the crux of her original research: atoms absorb light as two photons, simultaneously. To measure two-photon absorption, scientists now use the Goeppert Mayer (GM) unit.
Her PhD thesis in #physics in 1930 explored how atoms might interact with photons, and this work was described by and Nobel Laureate Eugene Wigner as “a masterpiece of clarity and concreteness”.

We all know Marie Curie was the first woman to win a @NobelPrize, but do you know who was the second? It was Maria Goeppert Mayer who was born #OnThisDay in 1906! 🎉
#Thread #TIL #WomenInScience https://t.co/1kvlrICkrn

He found that the X-rays became less intense — or had longer wavelengths — after hitting the target than before. This was due to the extra energy actually transferring from the X-rays to some of the electrons contained in the material. This became known as the Compton effect.

Happy Birthday, Arthur Compton!

Born on this day, Compton won the @NobelPrize in #Physics in 1927 for demonstrating the particle nature of electromagnetic radiation. He did this by shooting X-rays at a metal surface and observing how they behaved. #TIL #OTD https://t.co/5AvV9VQ8oQ

Bhabha played an important part in the formation of the Atomic Energy Commission in 1948 and the @DAEIndia in 1954. He also represented India at IAEA conferences.

Bhabha is often referred to as ‘the father of the Indian #nuclear programme’, reputation earned from his role in establishing the Cosmic Ray Research Unit at the Indian Institute of Science @iiscbangalore and from helping to formulate India’s strategy in nuclear power.
One of Bhabha’s most well-known achievements was deriving the correct expression of scattering positrons by electrons, which became known as Bhabha scattering.

Today is the birthday of Homi J. Bhabha, who is famous for his work on electron scattering and pioneering the nuclear energy programme in #India 🇮🇳!

In 1954, Bohr helped to establish the European Organization for Nuclear Research @CERN, and in 1955, he put together the Atoms for Peace Conference. Bohr received the #Atoms4Peace Award in 1957 for his continuous efforts to call for peaceful applications of atomic energy.

Bohr's theory could explain why atoms emit light in fixed wavelengths. Thanks to his fundamental contributions to understanding atomic structure and quantum theory, Bohr received the @NobelPrize in Physics in 1922.

Bohr’s #atomic model explains that electrons orbit the nucleus at certain distances. When an electron changes orbits, a light quantum is emitted. Photons are emitted as a result of the energy difference between the initial and final orbit.

Happy Birthday, Niels Bohr! 🎉⚛
Born #onthisday in 1885, Bohr is famous for his revolutionary theory on atomic structures and radiation emission.

Today, the periodic table of elements still reflects Moseley’s findings, and atomic batteries are now used in places where long battery life is crucial, like spacecraft for example. https://t.co/uMk3dK8Mps
By doing so, Moseley discovered a mathematical relationship between X-ray wavelengths and the atomic numbers of metals. This became known as Moseley’s law.
A year later, Moseley was able to determine X-ray wavelengths by observing and measuring the X-ray ranges of metals, thus pioneering the use of the X-ray Spectroscopy method.
In 1912, Moseley developed the first atomic battery, or beta cell, when he insulated beta particles emitted from radium to generate 150,000 volts of long-lasting energy.

Today is Henry Moseley’s birthday! 👏⚛

He was the inventor of the first atomic battery and the first scientist to give physical meaning to the atomic weights of the periodic table of elements. 

#TIL #Thread https://t.co/DHAnjIT3Gd

The XRF technique was also used to examine David, Michelangelo's masterpiece. By analysing the dust and dirt on David’s nose, experts confirmed the statue could be safely restored. https://t.co/8HUltmYA2Q

How does X-ray fluorescence spectrometry work? The beam is focused by an X-ray lens at a selected spot on the sample. The analysis takes a few minutes and does not harm the piece of art. Data from the analysis then reveals the sample's composition, confirming its authenticity. https://t.co/N0neQ5BkfC
With the help of equipment from the IAEA, experts discovered that the piece was in good condition and was in fact made of 90% pure gold. https://t.co/8qD59Nsr6u

After a three-year 🌍 search, #OnThisDay in 2006, police recovered the art piece from a forest outside #Vienna. Police and conservators turned to X-ray fluorescence spectrometry (XRF) to uncover clues about its condition and investigate how to best protect it further. https://t.co/EucnYK1IO0

When uranium is taken from the earth, the ore or rock typically contains only about 0.1% uranium. After extracting it and making it into a ‘yellowcake’, the uranium concentration in it has been raised to more than 75%!

500x more abundant than gold & as common as tin, uranium is a slightly radioactive metal that occurs throughout earth's crust. Most rocks & soils, and many rivers & seawater, contain uranium. Uranium-based fuel is expected to remain a basic, reliable source for low-carbon power.
#Uranium, the fuel that enables nuclear power plants to generate electricity, is a heavy, dense and radioactive metal. This makes it a potent source of concentrated energy.
What you see in this picture is “yellowcake” coming off a conveyor line. And what’s the main ingredient of yellowcake? That’s right: uranium! #TIL https://t.co/GFt56MRht0

178 countries have CSAs in force with the IAEA today, but Finland will always be special for being first!

Under a CSA, the IAEA has the right & obligation to ensure that safeguards are applied on all nuclear material, for the exclusive purpose of verifying that such material is not diverted to nuclear weapons or other nuclear explosive devices.

The NPT is the centrepiece of global efforts to prevent the spread of nuclear weapons. Article III of the NPT requires non-nuclear-weapon State parties to conclude a CSA with the IAEA so we can verify their peaceful use of nuclear material.

Congratulations #Finland on the 50th anniversary of your nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty (NPT) Comprehensive Safeguards Agreement (CSA) — the world's first ever NPT CSA to enter into force on this day in 1972!

Particle accelerators have many applications in medicine, industry and research. These machines accelerate charged particles, such as electrons and protons, to high speeds, sometimes even close to the speed of light. https://t.co/Pf1OvRMI4y

It was the first time one element had been changed to another under full human control. This discovery has helped scientists understand how they can manipulate particles on a subatomic level in an effort to better understand the structure and function of matter.

Cockcroft and Walton developed an accelerator that generates extremely penetrating radiation. They then used this accelerator to bombard lithium with protons and effectively split its nucleus into two helium atoms.

#TIL 🧵: 90 years ago #onthisday, the course of nuclear physics took a new turn when John Cockcroft and Ernest Walton split the atom ⚛️ using a particle accelerator for the first time. This achievement earned them the @NobelPrize in Physics in 1951. https://t.co/xgJej2EM0d

In 1961, Cockcroft received the Atoms for Peace Award for contributions to the development or application of peaceful nuclear tech. The award was created in response to Eisenhower’s Atoms for Peace address to the @UN — a speech that played a pivotal part in the birth of the IAEA.

In 1932 they bombarded lithium with protons and effectively split its nucleus into two helium atoms. It was the first time one element had been changed to another under full human control. This work earned them the 1951 @NobelPrize in Physics.
Beginning in 1928, Cockcroft and fellow scientist Ernest Walton worked on the acceleration of protons using a particle accelerator.

The first time an atom was successfully split using a particle accelerator was thanks in part to Sir John Cockcroft! He was born 125 years ago #onthisday.

🎉⚛ #Thread #TIL https://t.co/rxi3THNw4E

X-ray crystallography is critical in determining the structures of many biological molecules in order to understand their function.

Hodgkin used this version of the technique to determine the atomic and molecular structures of penicillin, insulin, and vitamin B12. Her work on protein crystallography earned her the @NoblePrize in Chemistry in 1964.

X-ray crystallography involves beams of X-rays hitting atoms of a crystal (like those found in materials such as salts, metals, minerals, and semiconductors), which are then diffracted into many different directions.

Hodgkin is most well-known for pioneering methods in the field of X-ray crystallography. She was able to determine the three-dimensional structures of biomolecules using a new technique called X-ray crystallography, which she helped to advance.

Today we celebrate the third woman to ever win the @NobelPrize in #Chemistry: Dorothy Hodgkin!

Why the IAEA needs to be allowed to go to Ukraine’s #Zaporizhzya Nuclear Power Plant? Director General @RafaelMGrossi spells out the reasons to #UNSC. Read our summary: https://t.co/MFEiLE0wSD https://t.co/nym9gAJu5d
"I thank #UN Secretary General @antonioguterres for his unwavering support, and the #UNSC for its indispensable focus on global safety and security."—@rafaelmgrossi at UNSC

"Our on-site presence at #Zaporizhzya NPP would provide a stabilizing influence. We have been ready since June, but due to political factors and other considerations, a mission has not been possible. We cannot allow such factors to delay us any longer."—@rafaelmgrossi at #UNSC

"IAEA experts would assess physical damage at #Zaporizhzya NPP, determine if main & backup safety and security systems are functional, and evaluate working conditions of control room staff. A mission would also allow us to perform urgent safeguards work."—@rafaelmgrossi at #UNSC

"I ask that both sides of this armed conflict cooperate with the IAEA and allow for a mission to the #Zaporizhzya NPP as soon as possible. Time is of the essence, so I propose to hold this mission as soon as possible."—@rafaelmgrossi at #UNSC

"Based on most recent information provided by #Ukraine, IAEA experts have preliminarily assessed that there is no immediate threat to nuclear safety as a result of the shelling or other recent military actions. However, this could change at any moment."—@rafaelmgrossi at #UNSC

"I remain very concerned about situation at #Zaporizhzya NPP and reiterate that any military actions jeopardizing nuclear safety & security must stop immediately. These military actions near such a large nuclear facility could have serious consequences."—@rafaelmgrossi at #UNSC

"Recently, the situation at the nuclear power facilities, particularly at #Zaporizhzya, has become alarming. As of today, the plant has limited availability of offsite power due to damage from the shelling last week."—@rafaelmgrossi at #UNSC
The IAEA has conducted 9 safeguards missions since the start of the war. 2 teams are in #Chornobyl now. —@rafaelmgrossi at #UNSC

"I have led 2 missions of experts to #Ukraine to provide necessary assistance at nuclear facilities; the IAEA has coordinated offers of assistance from our Member States of items such as personal protective equipment and radiation monitors."—@rafaelmgrossi at #UNSC

.@rafaelmgrossi at #UNSC: "Since 24 Feb IAEA has closely monitored the situation at nuclear facilities as well as activities involving radioactive sources & nuclear material in #Ukraine, focusing on implications for nuclear safety, security & safeguards." https://t.co/fmm6Li3dVQ

"The Treaty you are here to Review is vital to peace and development. That is why we must recommit to the NPT and protect it. The IAEA will be with you every step of the way."—@rafaelmgrossi at #NPTRevCon

"IAEA is where the international community keeps the promise implicit in the #NPT that peaceful nuclear technology will be accessible to all countries. Through our technical cooperation programme we bring this central principal of the NPT to life."—@rafaelmgrossi at #NPTRevCon

"Nuclear science and technology contributes directly to more than half the @UN #SDGs and indirectly to all of them. It cures diseases; helps feed the hungry; protects the environment, and powers progress without harming the environment."—@rafaelmgrossi at #NPTRevCon
“We cannot build a more secure world with more nuclear weapons in existing arsenals and if more countries seek to acquire them.”—@rafaelmgrossi at #NPTRevCon

"Countries are working on projects involving nuclear naval propulsion. This, while foreseen by the legal framework, raises questions that require appropriate technical answers to protect the integrity of the non-proliferation regime as we know it."—@rafaelmgrossi at #NPTRevCon

"The situation in the Korean peninsula is of serious concern. For the past 13 years, IAEA has not been present in the Democratic People’s Republic of Korea. IAEA is ready to return to the #DPRK as soon as a political agreement allows it to do so."—@rafaelmgrossi at #NPTRevCon

"If we are to offer credible assurances that Iran’s sizable and growing nuclear programme is exclusively for peaceful purposes, #Iran must grant IAEA inspectors access commensurate to the size of that programme and provide us complete information."—@rafaelmgrossi at #NPTRevCon

"A safeguards regime, reinforced by the additional protocol and the amended small quantities protocol, can give us all the trust and confidence we need that states using nuclear energy for the wellbeing of their people, are not hiding anything."—@rafaelmgrossi at #NPTRevCon

"While this war rages on, inaction is unconscionable. If an accident occurs at #Zaporizhzhya Nuclear Power Plant in #Ukraine we will not have a natural disaster to blame. We will have only ourselves to answer to."—@rafaelmgrossi at #NPTRevCon

"Nuclear is safer than it has ever been. But we are being tested once again. This time by war. War in #Ukraine is threatening one of the world’s biggest nuclear power programmes."—@rafaelmgrossi at #NPTRevCon

"Importance of nuclear energy is on the rise, as we face an energy crisis, energy security concerns prompted by war, and the increased climate urgency. This makes the work of the IAEA in nuclear safety and security all the more important."—@rafaelmgrossi at #NPTRevCon

"The IAEA is *the* place where 175 Member States partner with scientists, inspectors, diplomats, doctors, engineers, and many other experts to bring the NPT to life every day."—@rafaelmgrossi at #NPTRevCon

.@rafaelmgrossi at #NPTRevCon: "In this moment of global uncertainty, anxiety, fear and distress, we must come together and recommit to the noble principles enshrined in the NPT: nuclear non-proliferation, disarmament, & to promote cooperation in peaceful uses of nuclear energy."

"#DPRK’s nuclear programme is a clear violation of relevant #UNSC resolutions. I call upon DPRK to comply fully w/ obligations under #UNSC resolutions, to cooperate promptly w/ IAEA in full & effective implementation of its NPT Safeguards Agreement," @RafaelMGrossi

#JCPOA: "Unless & until #Iran provides technically credible explanations for presence of uranium particles of anthropogenic origin at 3 undeclared locations (...) IAEA won't be able to confirm Iran’s declarations under its Comprehensive Safeguards Agreement," @RafaelMGrossi

#JCPOA: "Since 23 Feb 2021, Agency’s verification and monitoring of Iran’s nuclear-related commitments under JCPOA have been seriously affected by #Iran’s decision to stop the implementation of those commitments, incl. its commitments under Additional Protocol," @RafaelMGrossi

#AUKUS: "I welcome AUKUS parties’ engagement w/ IAEA to date & expect this to continue (...) ensuring that the highest non-proliferation and safeguards standards are met. Agency will have its verification and non-proliferation mandate as its guiding principle," @RafaelMGrossi
#COP27: "IAEA will build on its achievements at last year’s #COP26 by highlighting the key role of nuclear energy in supporting #ClimateChange mitigation and adaptation," @RafaelMGrossi

#PoweredByNuclear: "Together w/ #USA, we are preparing for Int'l Ministerial Conference on Nuclear Power in the 21st Century. Conf will offer a forum for ministers, gov officials, industry, policymakers & experts to discuss challenges & opportunities for nuclear," @RafaelMGrossi

#ClimateChange: "More & more govs and members of the public are embracing nuclear power as a way out of today’s energy & climate crises. IAEA has revised upwards by 10% its latest high-case forecast for capacity growth in nuclear power generation up to 2050," @RafaelMGrossi

#CancerCare4All: "Thru ‘Rays of Hope’, we are working very closely with countries and other potential donors to secure the necessary funding to support countries in establishing their first radiation therapy facilities or expanding such services," @RafaelMGrossi

#NUTECPlastics: "Verification tests of proposed plastic waste recycling applications are underway. The IAEA’s efforts under NUTEC Plastics are now embedded in the work of the #G20, having been included in its most recent report," @RafaelMGrossi

#Ukraine: "Thru our ongoing presence & efforts to establish a Nuclear Safety & Security Protection Zone, we can reduce risk of an accident, improve conditions under which staff operates #ZNPP, and lay part of the foundation necessary for road to peace & security" @RafaelMGrossi

#Ukraine: "Based on the evaluation of all safeguards-relevant information available to the IAEA, we have not found any indication that would give rise to a proliferation concern," DG @RafaelMGrossi told BoG

#Ukraine: "A report on the work of the IAEA in assisting Ukraine and assessing the situation at its nuclear facilities (…) includes the latest information and recommendations by ISAMZ" - @rafaelmgrossi
